Foreign body in esophagus  Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure: Upper Endoscopy   History of Present Illness: 44 year old man with no known medical history who presents with a suspected foreign body in his esophagus. The patient was in his usual state of health until 5 PM on the evening prior to presentation when he developed hiccups while eating chicken.  He immediately felt as if something was stuck in his chest.  He was coughing and felt as if he was having mild difficulty breathing.  He also felt as if he was having difficulty swallowing his saliva.  This sensation worsened and he presented to [**Hospital1 **]. . He was initially taken to [**Hospital3 **].  Initial vitals there were T: 98.2 HR: 85 BP: 98/66 RR: 18 O2: 98% on RA.    He received glucagon, ativan and zofran which improved his symptoms.  He was transferred to this hospital for gastroenterology evaluation and endoscopy.  He vomitted en route and by the time he arrived here he noted that he was better able to swallow his saliva.  In our ED, initial vitals were: T 98, P 92, BP 143/96, R 18, O2 sat 99RA. On exam, he was speaking without difficulty and managing secretions. He had a CXR with no absolute evidence of foreign body in the esophagus.  He was seen by GI who recommended ICU admission for monitoring pending endoscopy in AM.  On arrival to the ICU he is well appearing, in no distress.  He endorses some mild discomfort in his mid chest and feels as if he is still having difficulty swallowing his saliva.  He feels mildy short of breath but does not have pain on deep inspiration.  He is urinating well.  He endorses mild nausea. Otherwise no fevers, chills, chest pain, abdominal pain, dysuria, hematuria, leg pain or swelling.  All other review of systems negative in detail.   Past Medical History: Allergic Rhinitis
